title: 105_hr437
content: The Act titled "National Sea Grant College Program Reauthorization Act of 1997" makes amendments to the National Sea Grant College Program Act (33 U.S.C. 1121 et seq.), including changes to definitions. The National Sea Grant College Program Reauthorization Act of 1997 amends the definitions in the National Sea Grant College Program Act. It defines a sea grant institution as any sea grant college, sea grant regional consortium, institution of higher education, institute, laboratory, or State/local agency conducting a sea grant program. It also expands the definition of "field related to ocean, coastal, and Great Lakes resources" to include disciplines like marine affairs, resource management, technology, education, and science. The term 'Secretary' in the National Sea Grant College Program Act now refers to the Secretary of Commerce, acting through the Under Secretary of Commerce for Oceans and Atmosphere. Amendments have been made to replace references to the 'Under Secretary' with 'Secretary' throughout the Act. SEC. 4 amends Section 204(a) by requiring the Secretary to consult with sea grant institutions and a panel for long-range planning guidelines. SEC. 5 outlines the duties of the Director. Section 204(c) (33 U.S.C. 1123(c)) is amended to specify the duties of the Director of the National Sea Grant College Program, who is responsible for advising the Secretary on available expertise, encouraging other federal entities to utilize program capabilities, and assisting in activities within the Administration. The Director of the National Sea Grant College Program is tasked with utilizing program capabilities, advising the Secretary on expertise, coordinating with other federal programs, overseeing sea grant institutions, and promoting the growth of sea grant programs. The Director evaluates and allocates funding among sea grant institutions to promote competition, successful program implementation, and achievement of program objectives. The Director allocates funding to sea grant institutions to ensure stable funding and compliance with merit review guidelines. Sea Grant institutions are required to develop and implement programs in consultation with the Secretary and a panel, following guidelines and priorities. They must also conduct merit reviews for project grants and contracts. Additionally, there is a provision for a Sea Grant International Program. SEC. 7 of the Sea Grant Program Improvement Act of 1976 is amended to focus on living marine resources. The program is set to be repealed with an effective date of October 1, 2000. SEC. 8 designates Sea Grant colleges and regional consortia. The Secretary can designate an institution of higher learning as a sea grant college or an association as a sea grant regional consortium if they maintain a program related to ocean resources, cooperate with others in the field, follow guidelines, and meet necessary qualifications. The Secretary shall establish guidelines for merit review of project proposals for grants and contracts under the National Sea Grant College Program. This includes peer review of research projects and standardized documentation requirements. The Secretary may suspend or terminate any designation under subsection (a) for cause after an opportunity for hearing. SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATIONS OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization for grants, contracts, and fellowships under the Act is set at $55.3 million for fiscal year 1998, $56.4 million for fiscal year 1999, and $57.5 million for fiscal year 2000. Funding for zebra mussel and oyster research includes up to $2.8 million for competitive grants for university research on the zebra mussel and up to $3 million for other research purposes. The Act authorizes grants, contracts, and fellowships totaling $55.3 million for fiscal year 1998, $56.4 million for fiscal year 1999, and $57.5 million for fiscal year 2000. Funding for oyster research includes up to $3 million for competitive grants for university research on oyster diseases and related human health risks. The text chunk discusses amendments to Section 212 (33 U.S.C. 1131) related to the National Sea Grant Office and the Administration. It includes changes to subsections and the repeal of subsection (c). Additionally, there is a prohibition on lobbying and notice of reprogramming or reorganization. The amended Section 212 prohibits lobbying activities with funds authorized and requires notice of reprogramming actions to be provided to appropriate committees. The Secretary must notify relevant committees before any major reorganization of the National Sea Grant College Program. SEC. 10. CLERICAL, CONFORMING, AND TECHNICAL AMENDMENTS. This section includes clerical amendments such as adjusting margins and headings in the National Sea Grant College Program. Section 209 (33 U.S.C. 1128) is amended to change the duties of the panel. Section 205(b)(3) (33 U.S.C. 1124(b)(3)) is amended by removing a specific reference. Section 204(d)(1) (33 U.S.C. 1123(d)(1)) is amended to adjust the number of positions and the maximum rate. Conforming amendments are made to Section 204(b)(2) (33 U.S.C. 1123(b)(2)). Section 209 (33 U.S.C. 1128) is amended to change duties of the panel and adjust rates. The maximum rate for GS-18 is replaced with a new maximum rate under section 5376 of title 5, United States Code. Technical amendments are made to section 209(c)(5)(A) to establish a new rate not exceeding the maximum daily rate payable under section 5376. SEC. 11. BUY AMERICAN. Entities receiving financial assistance under section 212(a) must comply with the Buy American Act and purchase American-made equipment. The Secretary of Commerce must notify recipients of this requirement. The House of Representatives passed the document on June 18, 1997. Attest: ROBIN H. CARLE, Clerk. By Ray Strong, Assistant to the Clerk.
